content.description:
Thin face climbing.  Shares an anchor with Tequila Doesn't Affect Me.



On the face with numerous bolted routes, there are two climbs which climb through cracks.  Apple Juice is between the two routes with cracks.  The anchor can be access from the top by using the tree anchor with green tat which is left of the tree with orange tat (when looking down).

8 bolts, bolted rap station

Very fun climbing up a smooth face.



On the main face there are 8 bolted routes.  Californian Hookers is to the right of Tabernac Crack (obvious crack).  This route can be accessed from the top using the left tree anchor with green tat (when looking down).

7 bolts, bolted hangers (no rappel rings)

Start left of Tequila but trend left.  Thin crimps all the way up to a bolted rap station at the top.  A tree anchor with orange tat can be used to lower to the anchor from the top.



To the right of the obvious overhang, there are 8 bolted routes. Passed Out is the first route right of the overhang.

From the top, a tree anchor with orange tat can be used to lower to the anchor.

8 bolts, bolted rap station.

Often wet, this is basically  nice 5.7 crack with a 5.11 roof start.  Great trad gear passes the roof which is a bit reachy.



On the left side of the Craig there is an obvious overhang.  Two routes are at the overhang; Trixie and Peace.  Peace is a mixed route with only 1 bolt.

1 Bolt, Tree Anchor

Climb up and to the right thru the 3 overhangs.  The bolts may be a bit sparse fro some.



This route is the furthest on the right.  The bolted route (4 bolts) is the shortest and trend up to the right.

4 bolts, bolted rap station

Crux is at the bottom then move into a moderate nice crack.  Two small cams for the crack are recommended.



On the main face with 8 bolted routes, there are two climbs which have cracks.  Tabernac Crack is the one on the right when viewing from the base (6 bolts).  This route can be accessed from the top using a tree anchor with green tat (tree with green tat furthest to the left when viewing from the top).

6 bolts, cams for the crack, bolted rap station.

Climb up through and between the double cracks.  Optional large nut in crack.



Find the only bolted line with double cracks.


8 bolts, bolted rap station.

Climb thru the overhang and up the awesome face, fun route.



This is the furthest left route when looking at the Craig from the water (9 bolts).  

9 Bolts, rings at the top.

Straight up small overlaps, good warmup route.



On the main face with 8 bolted routes, there are two routes on the right which are close together.  The one on the left is Venice Beach on the one on the right is Walala. This routes anchor can be accessed from the top using a large tree on the far left (when looking down).

7 bolts, bolted rap station.

Very nice climbing on good jugs.  Shares an anchor with Venice Beach.



There are 8 bolted routes on the main face.  On the right side, there are two bolted routes very close together.  The route on the right is Walala (Venice Beach is on the left).  They both share the same anchor.  The anchor can be accessed from the top using a tree anchor on the far left (when looking down).

7 bolts, bolted rap station

This is the obvious face on the backside of Loch Lomond Lake (can be seen from Route 820).  The rock offers lots of features which are surprisingly fun to climb and the experience is unique when belaying from a canoe or boat.  Top -roping can be setup  by landing a boat to the left of the Craig and walking to the top.  The water is not deep at the base of the cliff (2m or less) so a stick clip is recommended (this is not a deep water soloing spot).  Loch Lomond Craig gets a lot of sun in the day and provides and excellent opportunity to cool off in the water during the hot summer days.  If taking a boat, check the winds.  On windy days, the waves can pickup and toss the boat around at the bottom of the Craig.  The base has several hangers to fix your bow and stern while climbing.  Bring bumpers for your boat to prevent damage from it thrashing against the cliff.  The rock is Volcanogenic Lapilli Tuff which is pleasantly featured however can be crumbly in places (bing your helmet).  Due to the lack of traffic, the routes can be dirty with some lichen but the experience is so unique, it is worth the adventure.  Loch Lomond is located on City of Saint John land.
